physDesc.p: Several erasures in this homily alter 'naenig'-forms to 'naen'-forms. There are also a few additions by what may be a further hand; this hand adds 'grere' and '7 þeah' on 38r and some other things on 38r, plus possibly one 'nes' inserted on 38v. The same hand seems to add 'aenig ðinc dydon;' on 109r, and possibly makes some alterations on 111v-112r.

handNote.p: Main scribe of the manuscript. A square Anglo-Saxon miniscule, described by Ker as 'handsome'.

This is hand of the main Rochester reviser. Ker describes the hand as 'sprawling, but firm and well-marked', with e slightly ascending and open at the top. It should be noted that Ker's palaeographical description on p. 367 erroneously states that this hand is responsible for the homily on Paulinus in 'art. 76', but in fact the added Paulinus homily is Ker's art. 75. Digipal terms this hand the 'Principal Corrector'.

Emending hand, quite large and round, superficially similar to the Rochester reviser, ECHOE HandID DP0985, but lacking the long flourishes and tongues; erases and overwrites the main text, tail of g closed, favouring tall/long s. Top of the belly stroke of a often fails to cleanly connect to the top of the back stroke, which can create a sort of roofing effect.
Emending hand. Rectangular in aspect with pronounced lean to the right, minims quite closely set. Final e often with an upward-curling, hair-thin decorative tongue. Often uses round s.
Emending hand. Late reviser s. xii, Caroline r, could be responsible for major erasures cf. 39v.
Emending hand with wider ductus, rounder in aspect.

keywords.term: Devil’s Account of the Next World

s.w: ƿ y æ n&slongdes;umn y e &slongdes;
